message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history of heavy drinking and subsequent withdrawal symptoms point toward delirium tremens, which is caused by withdrawal from alcohol after chronic heavy use. One of the main mechanisms behind this condition is an increased activity of NMDA receptors in the brain. This overactivity leads to hyperexcitability and can cause the symptoms seen in this patient, such as agitation, confusion, and hallucinations. The other options, functional increase in GABA, increased inhibition of norepinephrine, and increased inhibition of glutamate, do not relate to the pathophysiology of delirium tremens.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient most likely has delirium tremens, a severe form of alcohol withdrawal syndrome. Increased activity of NMDA receptors is the underlying pathophysiologic mechanism. In alcoholics, long-term excessive alcohol consumption leads to down-regulation of NMDA receptors, which causes excitatory neurotransmitter glutamate to be more pronounced than inhibitory neurotransmitter GABA. When alcohol is abruptly stopped, an excess of glutamate can result in seizures, agitation, delirium, and hallucinations.
